text: Tried this beer while passing through on deployment. It was super sweet with a whiskey back... what I meant is that it had a Caramel chocolaty taste followed by cherries and plums and enough alcohol to take your breath away. But not too bad or overwhelming alcoholy-ness to it. I loved it and would be willing to wire some money to the next person who visits this brewhouse and send me a couple bottles back. ;)

Frisch vom Hahn im Brauhaus getrunken. Hat lt. Karte 11,5%. Ölig-klebiges Dunkelkupfer im Glas. In der Nase Malznoten. Hat eher Barley-Wein oder Malzlikörqualität. Im Nachtrunk erdig-würzig. Leichte Lakritzanklänge.

On tap at the brewpub. Klare dunkel orange braune Farbe, geringe bräunliche schaumkrone. Geruch intensiv malzig, süß karamellig, leicht holzig. Geschmack intensiv süß malzig, Gewürze, holzig, reife Früchte, alkoholisch, starkes Stück.

Flip top bottle thanks to Rich. Dark amber with fast subsiding head. Sweet molasses aroma, sweet malts, minor roast grains. Taste ratchets up the sweetness, normal doppelbock flavors, but extra sweet. Sweetness masks the higher ABV.
Flip top bottle thanks to rich. Pours out amber topped with a ring of a head. Nose is big malts pit fruit sugar. Taste is more of the heavy sweetness rich malts and some spice.
UPDATED: SEP 8, 2016 On tap at the brewery. This beer amazed me. Very dark and viscous, little soy sauce flavor. No real head on it. For a high abv German beer it was pretty delicious.

Vom Fass im Brauhaus. Rötlich braun und trüb. Schaum ist sofort weg. Es duftet nach Pflaume und Gewürze. Sehr spannend. Süsser Antrunk. Dörrpflaume, Getrockneter Apfel, Brot. Sehr weich und rund. Schlner langer fruchtig-schwerer Abgang.

Bottle: Cloudy, reddish-amber coloured, rapidly vanishing loose off-white head; fruits and caramel in the sweet nose, distinctive traces of Schnapps in the background; solid sweet flavour with hoppy traces, full bodied and a bit sticky; lingering sweet-fruity finish, some herbal-hoppy traces detectable, warming alcohol in the very end. Totally overrated

A simple bottle without information about the hops or malts.
A cloudy red brown beer with a very small Cappuccino head. Strong malty and heavy sweet, caramel, full body, flat carbonation, texture oily, 
(I have a 0.5l bottle without batch or best-before date.)

Cervesa amb gust a caramel barrejat amb fruites deshidratades i alcohol.
Cerveza con sabor a caramelo mezclado con frutas deshidratadas y alcohol.

Draught at the Vetter, Heidelberg, Germany. 
Dark brown color with a tiny light tan head.
Dark fruits, raisins, sweetness, marmalade and dark maltiness in the aroma.
The flavor is... Wow!? This is... strong! Dark fruits, sweetness, plums and alcohol. Alcohol is quite strongly present. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Klares Bernstein mit kleiner Schaumkrone. Sehr Malzig, süß, vollmundig, reife Früchte, sehr süffig.

Draft at source. Hazy dark brown
No head
Dark caramel malt aroma
Light carbonation boozy up front. Dried fruits dark malt sligh syrupy very nice

Pours a finger of head on a hazy brown body.
The aroma is mild to non-existent... grain?
The taste is caramel candy, malty sweet, touch of lemon, alcohol heat, cotton candy with a long finish.
The texture is medium and smooth.
Its really sweet, worth trying for the experience.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2016 Colore ambra scuro, schiuma quasi invisibile. Birra molto dolce, da degustare a fine pasto e preferibilmente nei mesi freddi. Non è facile da sorseggiare visto l?alcol così in evidenza. Una buona doppelbock che spinge molto sul lato dolce. Carbonazione bassa.
Color dark amber with almost no head. Arome sweet, fruits. Taste very sweet, alcohol, roasted, berries.
On tap. Pours a very dark brown color. The aroma is yeast, caramel and fruit. The flavour is sweet malty, sweet caramel and sweet fruit. Very sweet overall.

0,2 standard [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, HD. 33° and advertised 12,5° Abv. Viscous and opaque ruby chestnut with some off-white foam. At first near-sickeningly sweet maltgasmic nose of Vitamalz and Malzbonbon slowly gives way to tawny port and some roast chestnuts, still not all that inviting though (lager containment vs ale expressivity). Taste sees layers upon layers of cloying candy sweetness, whilst funnily remaining at least sippable: Sirop de Liège condensed pear and prune sirup, Malzbonbon, massive liquorice, soy and a sweet prune marmelade à bobonne. As it sits and you struggle to take another sip, the beer does develop a bit, mainly into confident desert porto wine territory (the supermarket version, not the Niepoort one), yet gracelessly refuses to shed its marmelade cloak and to really open up to any surprises: the yeast has done its job und macht Feierabend, the plump, double plato dish of fruit sirup is served: how many times will you dig in? N.B. Including the hefty bottle surcharge, this teutonic anomaly seems less worth is take-home entrance fee: this beer was an attraction in its heyday, 20 years ago. Happy Birthday, Süße Heidelberger Omma! An on-premise 0,2L pour makes a great sipper... for a table of 4. Hard to rate, as it is perfectly that which it wants to be: malt soy. If you are viscousy thirsting for one of these, then youve sure picked a good one here. (Interesting side-by-side pairing: bocked ale artistry by De Struise Brouwers, wonders of drinkability at +12%).

Dark brown in colour, oil-like appearance, almost no head. The taste is very sweet, malty and reminds of the Finnish "Mämmi". Slight burn of alcohol in the finish makes. Taking into account that it packs 33 Plato, it is surprisingly well-balanced, but the 0.5 litre bottle is just bit too much.
Gejl, ihatatlan, hatásvadász Guiness-rekorder malátalikőr. Szégyellje magát.

Draught at the BrewPub. It pours cloudy near black with a thick dark beige head. The nose is sweet, sticky, treacle, candy and dried fruits. The taste is sweet.... liquorice, toffee, treacle, molasses, raisin, sugar, cola and candy with a pretty sweet finish. Medium-full body, average carbonation and sticky, viscous mouth-feel. Sweetness is pretty damn cloying after a while. Fun to try, but too sweet for my liking.

Draft at the brewery. 
Color: very black, almost no head. Could have been cola instead.
Aroma: caramel and alcohol
Taste: Really extremely sweet and syrupy. The alcohol is there, but no too prominent. 
Overall: Too sweet for me. Is this beer? Looks like flat cola and tastes even sweeter than that. Judging by the other rates, some people apparently like this profile; I dont.
Strong aroma of molasses and strawberries. Beautiful rich, dark amber. Taste is sweet with berries and molasses, without any strong alcoholic flavor. Palate is a bit thick.

Dark and very strong. Huge aroma of chocolate and alcohol. First sample I had was quite clear, the second two days later was as opaque as industrial adhesive. Unfortunately this beer confirms my suspicions that the best way to achieve high ratings on this site is to brew something the strength of wood alcohol. This is OK as far as it goes and quite a decent digestif once in a while, but surely thats not really what beer is about.
Opaque, dark amber/caramel in color color. Aroma is pretty near to strawberry jam. Full body and extremely sweet, but manages not to be sticky or cloying. Excellent.

I took three 33cl bottles home from the brewery. And when I opened the first one we were three people drink it. It is so thick that is almost caramel. And so dense and heavy that you dont need a lunch. I have to go back to Heidelberg and have it again.
Draft from brewery. One of the best beers I ever had. The explosion of extremely fine bubbles in your mouth... I have never experienced a doppelbock like this one before.
The head is medium, the body black. It smells roasty, a bit alcoholic, creamy, a bit tomato, brown sugar. The taste is brown sugary, roasty, spicy. Nice and interesting one! 11/11/10/11/-/11

1/VIII/2012 - on tap @ Vetter Brauhaus - BB: n/a - (2012-805) 
Note: 97? Are you f*ck*ng kidding me? Ridiculous. Well, I got it down to 96. :-p
Clear dark brown cola like beer, small aery beige to light brown head, unstable, dissipates quickly, non adhesive. Aroma: sweet, sugary, some caramel, dried fruits, and it took me a while to get it, but its mainly strawberry flavoured candy. MF: soft carbon, medium to full body, very syrupy, very sticky cloying sugary. Taste: lots of strawberry candy, heavy on the sugar, caramel, more sugar, little lemony. Aftertaste: little sour, strawberry candy, very sweet, caramel, mainly sugar. This is sickening sweet, and pretty bad.

dark brown color, rich raisiny nose with dark fruit, mollasses and dark chocolate. Very heavy, syrupy, but not cloying mouth. Full full bodied. Sweet and malty. Decent, but nothing too special for the style.

200ml Draft at Vetters Brauhaus in Heidelberg.  Appearance is deep, dark brown color with almost no head.  Aroma is malty, fruity, grains, and caramel.  Taste is heavy with flavors of brown sugar, roasted malts, caramel, and plum.  High alcohol content is well masked although it has a nice, warm boozy quality.  Palate is full-bodied, heavy, flat carbonation, thick texture, and a sweet finish.  This aint a normal Doppelbock for sure - almost reminds me of a Quad.  Great nonetheless.

#1409 draught; nose is rotten fruit, some red apple. sweet, velvet alcohol, sweet hazel note, mediumbroad sweet malt, feel is broad, carb is mediumlow, taste is broad hazel, syrup, sweet alcohol, some mediumsour earth

Tap at brewpub.  Pours dark brown with ruby highlights and a small, fizzy tan head, medium-short retention with light lacing.  Aroma is cookie, caramel, and nutty malt, plum, figs, and dates with toffee notes.  Flavor is malt dominant, heavy dark fruity esters, light alcohol, fruity bouquet and a sweet finish.  Full body, medium warmth and carbonation.

Enjoyed on tap at Vetter in Heidelberg, Germany while eating a meal with a co-worker prior to a work trip.  Appearance a dark rubyish with a rich white head, looked decadent served in a tall glass.  Aroma of sweetness, had notes of caramel and alcohol, smelled decadent.  Taste really was fantastic, definitely sweet but went down dangerously smooth and to me, didnt taste anything like an 10+% ABV brew.  Really happy to have had the opportunity to try this unique brew.

Süßer, fast zuckriger Schokoladenmalzbeginn. Wenig alkoholisch, zu Beginn kurzer geringer Hopfen. Dann zunehmend malziger, harmonisch, vollmundig. Komplex, karamellig, gut. Langer, schnell geringer werdender Malzausklang. Hat was! 11/11/12/12/13/13

Bottle at he Wasanas Winter Beer Tasting 2012! Thanks a lot, Bierkrug!!!

In the glass the beer is black, ruby red, with brown-yellow foam. Smells malty sweet, intense roasty and caramel-sugary. Slightly liqueur-like. Starts with lots of sweet malts, slightly alcoholic, strong aroma of caramelized sugar. Very intense aroma of roasted malts, caramel and toffee. Goes into a sugary-sweet finish, light burning in the throat. Absolutely brilliant beer!

500 ml flip-top bottle at Wasanas Winter Beer Tasting 2012, Idar-Oberstein, Germany. Pours a dark black that forms a tan very small just covering the blackness sheen. Aroma is candied malt, stones, caramel and alcohol. Taste is strong malt, alcohol, cereal and grains. Palate is bitter and lasting. Good but not as good as all of the hype.
Bottle. Dark clear brown color, tan head. Aroma of subtle brown bread. Taste is nice brandied butterscotch.
Please standby for a real rating. Im actually enjoying the company of other beer enthusiasts instead of being a non-social "I must rate this right now!!!"
On tap at Vetter Alt Heidelberger Brauhaus. This beer would make a great apertif, as its poured in small amounts. Very strong beer, served in small glass. Intensely sweet, no head. Delicious.
Brown and red with almost no head. Enormous thick consistency, very sweet and fruity. no alcoholic taste. smell of kiwi, pineapple and berries. enormous body and creamy-thick.

the king of bocks! holy moses this was sweet! sampled at the source, amazingly sticky sweet, not so carbonated. Very old school candy aroma, some herbs and malts. Brown with a small head. Very high on sweetness, heavy palate and overall a fantastic brew and at that moment on a Heidelberg night, this was pure heaven!
UPDATED: NOV 18, 2012 On tap at Vetters Heidelberg. Very dark black. Suprisingly sweet...as sweet as can be without being too sweet.

Bottled. Deep murky reddish brown colour with a mediumsized off-white to beige head, that leaves some slight lace. Aroma is sweet malts, bready malts, some raisins, mild sugar, syrup as well as some caramel. Flavour is being quite similar along with some dark dry gruits and mild spicyness and alcohol. Even though the alcohol is rather strong it suits the brew very well.

Draught. Copper coloured. Tall reddish beige head. Clear. Thick caramelly malty aroma. Extremely rich with a lot of sweetish caramel. Lots of flavour. Not sickly sweet, but very sweet, but still balanced and drinkable. Complex flavours. Something really special. I like it a lot.
The best beer Ive had from Germany. Dark caramels, bright with not much oxidation, thick and textured with a bit of chew, some light cocoas and biscuity flavors. Full aroma. Lightly sweet.

Small swingtop bottle, courtesy of Schutzenliesel (brought back straight from Germany). Thanks, Tom!  Pours a murky, slightly oily, brownish color; minimal off-white head; nice, oily, viscous pour. Solid caramel, brown sugar, and tempered alcohol in the nose; smooth, caramel. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: loads of oily caramel, sweet maltiness, and viscous brown sugar; oily, dense, smooth, and lovely; no alcohol; great stuff. Lengthy finish: caramel, sweet malts, light brown sugar; balanced end.
A fantastic choice. One would never know that it was 66 proof. A deep, brown appearance with a very smooth, yet delicious rest upon the palate. A must try when visiting Heidelberg.

(on tap @ Vetter Brauhaus) This beer was as close to perfect as you could get to a great Barley Wine. Not really sure why this site has it as a doppelbock. Black reddish body with a thin layer of cream head. Laced well. Low carbonation with the taste of huge malts and sugars without being cloying. This is a freakin HUGE beer. Very enjoyable on a cold day. It kind of makes you want to drink it all throughout winter. I will re-rate this again when I revisit Heidelberg soon.
Tap at Plan B. No head. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are rye bread, malt, fruits, caramel and syrop. Extremely thick and syropy.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2010 (draught, at the brewpub) pours a murky brown colour with a tall tanned head. interesting aroma of freshly squeezed apple juice, coffee beans, roasted malts, earth and caramel. flavour is strong coffee and earth, with light grain, marzipan, milk chocolate and a distinct honey finish, very sweet, but never cloying, almost sherry-like. highly viscous body with a smooth, oily texture and mild carbonation.

On tap at Plan B. Deep reddish brown body with a thin beige head. Heavy sweet malty aroma with notes of raisin, prune and sugar. Flavour is very sweet malty with overripe fruity notes, sugar and alcohol. Soft body. Long alcoholic finish.

[33cl swing top bottle] Hazy, murky opaque colour with a short beige foamy layer. Sweet and strong malty aroma with roasted elements, caramel, marzipan, molasses, subtle fruity notes of dates and figs and traces of alcohol. Sweet flavour, full bodied with a soft carbonation and an almost oily mouthfeel. Fat toast-malty taste with caramel, marzipan and shy traces of dried fruits. Sweet, strong malty and lasting finish with a balancing bitterness and a warming alcoholic touch. Nice and definitely not cloying but I prefer a Riesling Beerenauslese or Eiswein for the desert [24.I.09].
Draught at Plan B.Deep reddish colour with no head.Aroma of dry fruits and berries,feels very sweet and warming.Flavor is heavy and oily but really nice.

On tap at Plan B, Copenhagen. It serves a slightly hazy ruby to brown body, topped by a small, beige head. The aroma has an incredible malty sweetness, some roasted malt, caramel and dried fruits. Malty-sweet and roasted flavor with dried fruits, some alcohol and more raisins. Lasting finish with sweetness and roasted malt. Oily, sticky and full-bodied. A surprisingly good beer, considering its close to liquid malt-candy. Not high on drinkability, but lovely in a way. (080913)

Draught @ Plan B, Frederiksborggade 48, 1360 Copenhagen, Denmark.Clear medium to dark reb brown color (ala cola) with a virtually none head. Aroma is moderate malty, dark bread ala "pumpernikel", berry sweet - sour, dry fruits. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat. (050908)
Cloudy reddish brown with tiny off white head. Very sweet aroma with notes of plums , caramel and roasted malt. Cloying sweet flavour with plums, caramel, prunes and rye bread. Boozy finish.

From tap. Dark reddish brown with a tiny, disappearing beige head. Aroma is so intense malty that its difficult for me to sense so much more. Flavor is much more complex, concentrated sweet malt, dry fruit, Soya souse, molasses or maybe syrup. The palate is sticky and oily. A heavy and complex beer to be enjoyed in small amounts but still balanced somehow and hides the high alcohol really well.
Tap.  Astringent prune malt aroma.  Dark brown color with small long lasting head.  Molasses/chocolate malt flavor with moderate astringency.  Nice thick palate - sweet without being cloying.

Dark ruby red colored with vanishing yellow head. Strongly sweet caramelly aroma with coffee beans, chocolate, burnt sugar, brandy like alcohol also comes up. Near full bodied. Flavor is also strongly sweet with same caramel note, sugary palate. Aftertaste is mildly alcoholic. Well, hard to describe, lots of sweetness and alcohol.

Draught @ Plan B. Nice ruby brown, not much head. A little vinous, buttery aroma with dried fruits, prunes and a hint of spices. Intensive syrupy malty flavor, dried fruits, liquorice, butter, a bit oxidized feeling. Full bodied, oily palate. A huge bock, 20cl was a bit too much even.
20cl draft, plan-b cph. not much aroma, flavor is candy and dark fruits, sugar, caramel, toffee  - actually tastes more like a liquer than a beer. strange brew, but okay taste.

200ml on tap at Plan B, Copenhagen. Served in a special glass at ambient temperature. Very dark, ruby-tinted body. Circular bubbly edge at the surface. Strong, bready smell. Figs and prunes in the flavour against a dark malty backbone. Almost like drinking sweet roasted figs. Full and flat mouthfeel. Sophisticated bock, but only drinkable in small doses(02.06.2008).

Small yellowish beige head. Brown body with light carbonation. Intense sweet strawberry aroma with malty sugary notes. Intense sweet rock candy, chocolate, and toffee taste with marzipan notes. (Thats a taste dominated by four sweet things. Did I mention it was sweet yet?) Powerful alcohol heat and sharpness. Dense, gasoline-like moiuthfeel. Sweet roasty toffee and marzipan aftertaste with earthy roasty almond notes. Overwhelmingly sugary with quite a lot of chocolate. Nobody could call this a balanced beer. Had to drink water in between. In fact, its hard to drink even 0.2l of this. A unique beer. Interesting, and somewhat good, but tough. (0.2l draft at the brewpub.)

On tap - Plan B, Copenhagen.
Dark brown colour with virtually no head. Sweet, exceptional malty aroma. Gives rememberance to childhood walkings through the Carlsberg Brewey buildings in Copenhagen. Taste not surprisingly sweet -a liquid mixture of plums and dark brown bread. Almost like port. Sehr gut.
Brown with a creamy off-white head. Strong bready malt aroma, with vineous prune notes. Extremely sweet malty flavour, with some alcohol and a full body.

On tap @ Plan B, Copenhagen. Crystal clear, deep ruby colored body. No head, only a thin ring of foam clinging to the glass. The sweetest maltaroma ever. Also some inviting notes of English fruitcake and syrup-soaked fruits. Taste is very sweet, has a stong vineous characther with sweet and sour cherries, molasses, plum-marmelade and rum. Fat body. Syrupy mouthfeel. This beer is an extraordinary experience with a heavy sweetness all over, and it  actually works.  A really nice one.

Draught at PlanB.
Redbrown with a light brown head, no lavings. Aroma heavy malty (caramel, notes of very dark fruits). GFlavor heavy sweet, rests of malts. Creamy, oily, almost flat. Very pleasant.

Draught. No head at all. Very dark red brown body. Vineous, or should I say red wine like, aroma with a spicy touch plus a good deal of alcohol. Strangely enough the flavor is sorte of prunes plus alcohol. Rather sweet but in a pleasant way. Low carbonation and a long sweet aftertaste.

Tap at Plan B, Copenhagen: Deep ruby and purple highlights glint beneath a tiny rim of a head. Aroma of pure treacle. In fact, aroma, flavour, and mouthfeel really (albeit thinned down for the latter). I also found some inviting vinous quince notes too. Extraordinarily sweet, creamy crystal and treacle with a slight spice that I suspect is yeasty in origin. Super thick mouthfeel, awesome strong flavours. Yum!

Draught at Plan B, Copenhagen. Thx Jacob.
Hazy, deep golden.
Extremely malty aroma with loads of sweet fruits.
Oliy and thick palate.
Figs, prune, raisins.

[bottle purchased from brewpub]
Aroma promises a strong and very malty beer, with a healthy dose of German noble hops.  Also lots of dried fruit in the nose.  The appearance also promises something heavy--viscous opaque black liquid with a dark yellow head of fine bubbles that drops down to a thick ring after not too long.  Rich, velvety liquid with strong molasses-pumpernickel flavour that blends well with the high alcohol.  Some dried fruit flavors come out later in the taste, mingling together with a bitterness at the back of the tongue.  The beer is delicious for 2/3 of the experience, but then it seems to hit  a wall somehow.  The velvety sweet taste just disappears to leave sort of a dry sherry flavour lingering.  Sticky but not overly sweet, with appropriate bitterness.  Huge body, medium carbonation, nutty-bitter finish, but not astringent.
Draught. Murky dark brown colour. Sweet roasty caramel and yeasty aroma. Sweet, yeasty, bit spiced flavour with roasted malt and caramel. Sweet finish.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2008 Tap @ Plan B, Cph. [thanks for sharing, Grovlam]
Pours a muddy brown, wonderful when poured, but quickly turns into a unappetizing look. Sweet, lightly chocolate aroma with some roasted malts, liqourice and herbal hops. Very oily mouthfeel, low carbonation. Flavour is vinious, some port, toffee and lots of dried fruits. Sticky and sweet (perhaps a touch to sweet for my liking)

Draught @ Plan B. Extremely nice looking beer as it was being poured into the glass. Reddish / beige average head that was quickly goon. Volcanic bubbles forming from the ground up. Reddish brown color with an almost muddy look. Spare to no lacework. Aroma was quit complex alcoholic in a good way, with notes of bread, caramel / toffee, fruit and some herbal like notes as well. Over the palate toasted malt, dried fruit mix and apricot feel. Full bodied with a thick and alcoholic texture with a soft carbonation. Heavy sweet with a hint of acidic flavor. Heavy dried fruity sweet and lingering finish. Very nice!

Draught at Plan B, Copenhagen. Thanks to Jacob! Hazy amber color, yellowish head. Aroma from sweet fruits, raisins, pine apple and with vinous notes.  Sweet flavor, raisins. fruits, figs, , very oily palte. Very, very sweet, but I cant deny the fact I like it alot...

Courtesy of Degarth. Pours a clear brown to amber with no head. The aroma is sweet roasted malts, molasses and brown sugar along with fruit esters like prunes and dates along with a hint of alcohol. The taste is bold up front with sweet caramel candy mixed with prunes, plums, sweet raisins and molasses. Tasty. It ends with caramel sweetness, some alcohol (pretty well hidden for the ABV) and light dark fruitiness.

Courtesy of Degarth. Cool history behind this beer. Very still pour, plum colored body with no head, very Barley Wine like. Big nose - plums, raisins, prunes, figs, chocolate malts, grape jam and fusels. Grape jam stuck with me for some reason, and its more pronounced in the flavor composition, along with molasses, the fruits and malts. Very sweet beer overall, but in a smaller sample its not overpowering. Medium bodied, sticky mouthfeel. Finish is syrupy sweet. Amazingly this beer shares a lot in common with a BW, from the appearance to the flavor profile, just missing a dose of tropical fruits. Good beer.

on tap at plan b, copenhagen. thick pruple with no real head to speak of. aroma of butterscotch schnapps and vanilla. very thick, syruppy texture, unsurprisingly sweet but quite drinkable considering its strength

(Draught at Plan B, Copenhagen, 4 Aug 2007) Dark ruby colour with small head. Malty, sweet nose with wort, a bit like malt syrup. Malty, sweet taste with wort, raisins, prunes, dark rye bread. Ginger biscuits and cinnamon in the finish. Full body, thick and syrupy mouthfeel. Hops overshadowed by overpowering malt and wort. Not very discreet, but very nice in moderate amounts.

From tap at plan b. Pours dark brown/amber with no lasting head. Thick sweet brewmash and berry aroma, very very sweet. Flavour is by far the sweetest thing Ive tasted. Heavy berry note and cornish flavour too. Slight burned/roasted note. Burned finish. Alcohol does give a warming feel but does not really burn. This is perhaps the only really sweet beer Ive enjoyed.

Draught at Plan B, the aroma is full of figgs, raisens and honey - it is a bit similar to a mead. The flavor is similar with the fruit, but also the malt. There is no head. A great beer very similar to a mead sweet - good for dessert!
Tap, Plan B. Hazy brown color, short head. Sweet malty aroma, caraml. Strong taste, slight alcoholic, very sweet as well, caramel malt, some sugar. Sticky palate.

A Mes rate: 
Draught @ Plan B. Glorious thick red brown amber colour. Nose is just a little too much of an assault on the senses. Heavy barley in the flavour that burns a little on the way down but in a good way. Lovely and thich and rich with dark fruit. Unusual, interesting and tasty.

Draught at Plan B. Deep reddish - offwhite head. Lots of dried dark fruits, raisins, plums, prunes, medium sweetness, chokolate, licorice. I had this first time at ØLbaren - Rene brought it (Bottled) for a DØE-membersevening - it was thick and sirupy. This seemes more lightbodied !!

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2007 Dark amber, small head, sweet, malty aroma. Full bodied. A bit cloying. Caramel, molasses, hint of toffee, and fruit. Alcohol not strong. Billed as the worlds strongest beer, in 1994. With the 33 Plato OG, it apparently could have fermented out a little more and then wouldnt be so sweet. Overall I thought the beer to be just slightly above average.

Brown glass bottle with a ceramic pop-top from the brewery.  Beautiful slightly hazy dark red body with only a slight film of off-white body.  Looks very thick/syrupy as it pours.  Smells roasty and nutty with just a hint of alcohol.  Tastes nutty with hints of caramel.  Alcohol flavor is almost non-existent, though alcohol warming is definitely present at the back of the throat as it goes down.  Mouthfeel is slightly syrupy, but surprisingly drinkable despite this.  Not a lot of carbonation.  Wow.  This beer is fantastic.  Similar to Samichlaus Bier in some ways, but I find this one to be more drinkable, and it tastes better IMO.  Id get this again in a heartbeat if it was sold here.

From the bottle, courtesy of a new found best friend who had just come from Baden-Württemberg and picked this up at the Bräuhaus in Heidelberg. As though starved for alcohol, this had to be the best night cap Ive ever had, or atleast whilst in a foreign country, a lively hostel, enjoying the merriment of München, Germany. Harsh!!!Into clear plastic cups - only the finest will do - it poured a crimson amber with much conditioning showing in its sparse, minute carbonation. Head was just a paper sheet of tight bubbles, shaded off-white which managed to hold. No lace due ofcourse to the cup involved. A big hit of malt on the nose initially; clean, sweetish but still well-defined, gritty and grainy. It subsides, alcohol kicks in as does some savoury sultanas, dried peaches and a good settling in of fresh baked Stollenkuche. It drips, it oozes the alcohol but it doesnt lose that typically Deutsch Reinheitsgebot character. It sits well in the mouth, liqueurish, hot but not overdone and heavily enveloped the alcohol is in so much malt. It is like liquid bread, a huge body, silky, viscous on the tongue and oh so warming. Its concentrated Mai-bock. Sweet honey, darker more mulled honey mid-palate, a lot of scrumptious toasted malt hinting an edge of savoury fruits, some strange anise along the sides, a little fresh ginger and pepper-spice in back before a very sweet, complex malt swallow that was like elixir. It was medicinal but in a good way, never have I had a lager you could stand a spoon up in. This was thick, gooey, magnificently malty fun. It worked a treat, slept like a baby. Glad to have tried this once World record holder. (50cL, didnt get the date, 11%ABV)
A much different doppelbock than what I was expecting, perhaps a little too intense.  Thick and syrupy-sweet with little carbonation.  Ruby red.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Head fades fast.

Herbal aroma, herbal and liquorice flavour. Reminds me of Fernet Branca, which is good since I love that liquor.

Due to a misunderstanding  which had me truly baffled  I thought it was 33% ABV and not Plato. Funny thing is, I was ready to believe it after tasting it!

I didnt dare to drink the whole glass, since I was starting my evening and didnt wish to become wasted.  Either way, the excellent Plan B was about to close and thats not a beer to drink fast.

I noted it should come in smaller glasses, but given its 10,5% and not 33% Ill take a small draft and drink it all. Slowly.
Copenhagen (bottle?). After the initial hit of Benedryl, very tasty. Would it be too cliched to say it was like drinking black silk? Too late, I already said it.
Draught. Dark reddish brown with no head. Raisins, fruit, dates, sweetness and alcohol in aroma. Sweet flavour with malt, raisins, brown sugar and roasted malts in flavour. Lovely...

Pours dark caramel with a mostly receding off-white head. Aroma of caramelized wort, toffee, and plums. Taste is caramelized wort and sticky sweet. Mouthfeel is full bodied and sticky with smooth carbonation.

(Draught at Plan B, Copenhagen) Pours red/brown with no head. Smells dark bread syrup and cherrie chocolate. Raisins and other dried fruits. The taste is oily and alcohol-ish. Peppery and dried fruits. Fudge. Sweet and sugary malt. More carbnation then you would think looking at the pouring. Good, thick body.
tap. murky brown color. sweet malty aroma. liqerice hit me right way. other than that: super sweet and very alcohollic. nice pallete though.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2012 2011-10-04, draught at the brewpub, 7-4-8-3-15=37Brown color, with amber shades; the head has a short retention. Nice aroma of sweet caramel, with mild fruity touch and light alcohol perception. Full bodied, with round and sweet mouthfeel, caramel flavor with a touch of roasted malt, from which the bitterness seems to come from; some alcohol too, but not too invasive. Unbalanced, but can be appreciated.2010-09-07, draught at the brewpub, listed at 11.5% ABV, 7-4-7-3-15=36Dark mahogany color, with red shades, hazy. Very nice aroma, caramel, fruits, cooked prunes, like a Tarte Tatin, sweet; very peculiar. Solid body, thick, syrupy, with a strong flavor of caramel and stewed fruits. In the end, with the ultra-sweet caramel, there is a light trace of Parmigiano Reggiano cheese, actually not the first beer with this trait, and light sweet liquorice. Correct bitterness. Very good but demanding.2009-02-07, draught at Plan B, Copenhagen 7-3-8-4-15=37Flat, with no head; brown color with red shades. Sweet caramel aroma. Thick body, with a lot of caramel, very sweet, traces of chocolate, bitter enough this time. The alcohol creates a nice warming feeling. Very good.2006-06-04, draught at Plan B, Copenhagen, 7-3-7-3-14=34Flat, dark amber color. Malty, soft and with a lot of caramel; warming. Very sweet, not bitter enough. Not bad, but Eku 28 is more interesting.

Draught  Brown body with red shine, head away faster you can blink your eyes; very big sugar (brown and dark muscovado), syrup, little metallic (like white sugar), spicy (like boiled down soy sauce) nose; very sweet body, syrup like oily, sticky texture; long, long complex finish, extremely sweet with a very nice and much needed accompanying bitterness, aromas are very much like the nose. Great and very special beers that sticks everywhere, the glass, your fingers, lips etc.
On tap at Plan B. Dark brown with no head. Very very sweet and very very strong and alcoholic. Kinda strange.

Draught!!  Dark brown; no head left. The nose is a mix of meat gravy and soy sauce. Unbelievable. Soy sauce taste, very sweet (Chinese dark and Ketjap Manis) over other hints. I get some malts (well, I reckon a ton in the glass), but it is muddled by all the sugar. I can nearly chew on this - its like mashed beef in syrup. IMO, this is no longer a beer. Interesting? Yes. Pleasing - I fear not.
Bottle brought home by sk8viking. Chestnut color. Nice full body with a sweet note of raisins and slight alcohol. Nice and warming.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2009 Hazy dark red, creamy brown head. Dried sweet fig aroma. Berries, port. 
Highly viscous sweet molassis base, peppery, strawberry notes, light chocolate and coffee  Roasted caramelly retronasal. Old rating:Sampled at the RBESP 2005
Dark red brown, low head.
Dark dark sugar aroma, spiced fruit. Rich sugary, plums, molassis, quite sweet. Oily thick mouthfeel.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2009 Draught, 11.5% at the brewpub. Not much aroma, perhaps a little liquorice. Dark brown colour, red shine. Clear or hazy. Looks a bit like cola. No head. Thick, syrupy, sugary mouthfeel. The flavour is quite sweet, has some malt syrup notes. Balanced by a bit of alcohol, which by the way is not that prominent considering the ABV. The flavour is sugary, of course, caramelly and slightly burnt. At first it tastes a bit of liquorice, but that goes away after a while. 7 3 7 3 16



Draught at plan b. Malty, grainy, worty aroma. Cloudy dark brown colour. No head. Very malty flavour, twice as malty as most barley wines. The mouthfeel is VERY thick and syrupy, like pineapple juice or something. But the flavour is obviously a lot better, very sweet and malty. Must be the thickest beer I ever had. A lot like Chinese soups. 7 3 9 3 18

Bottle at RBESG Grand Tasting, August 2005. Ill admit at the outset that Im not a big fan of Doppelbocks, but this was particularly hard going. Absurdly sweet. Viscous, sticky mouthfeel. Exaggerated soy sauce, balsamic vinegar, phenolics and cough medicine on the nose. More soy sauce on the palate, with a really thick worty malt element - like drinking malt extract. Im sure this would work quite well as a stir-fry marinade but, as a beer, its a no-no (for me at least). I could cope with the other elements, were it not for the excessive sweetness.

On tap @ VettersOne of the most peculiar beers Ive tried. Comes jet black with almost no head. Aroma is sweet. Taste is also sweet with herbs - quite pleasant. The mouthfeel is what sets this apart. Its like what I imagine oil must feel like - incredibly viscuous. The alcohol is contained somewhere inside, I couldnt taste it.
Fabulous, full on bock. Tight but mildly aromatic arome, big flavousome palate with a clean if slightly hot alcohol finish. Just the brew for a late winters stumble back to our hotle in Heidelberg.

Dark fruit, alcohol, liquorice and soy notes to the lightly roasty cocoa aroma.  Opaque brown, liquorous, viscous body with no head.  Cake-like sweetness to the nutty, dark fruit flavour with some soy notes and alcohol very apparent in the finish.  Full body with low carbonation and strong alcohol warming.    EZ cap bottle/growler at RBESG 2005.

Opaque brown.
Alcoholic aroma with acidic touch.
Chocolate flavor with notes of fudge, fruit, alcohol and leafs. Some bitterness. Sweet.

Hand-bottled 1L bottle from sk8viking... made its way to Wisconsin with no damage :)  Poured a very deep ruby-brown.  Into a snifter, there was an instantly-diminishing head... but the pils glass yielded a fairly well-sustained creamy caramel head.  Aroma was powerfully vinous at first, with a huge nose of very sweet roasted malts.  Flavor was primarily of dark fruits with increasing alcohol as this warmed.  Very full and creamy on the palate... with just the right amount of carbonation.  Hit just about all the taste buds.  Finish was medium-length, with sweet berries, grapes, and alcohol warmth.  Left the lips a little sticky.  This brew was malt-tastic!
Bottle. Really really over the top caramel sweetness and soy sauce stickyness. Alcohol is noticed. Too much sweetness for me.
RBESG 2005. Very sweet, dark brown red colour. Not much carbo. Burned aroma of malt. Big mouthfull. Some alcoholic taste, but not bad.
RBESG05: Light coffee, big toffee in nose. Dark amber with a tan head. A little cloying and over the top, but drinkable.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2005 Bottled at RBESG.  Dark brown, no head. Loads of toffee paired with syrup. Soft and very malty with sticky mouthfeel and salty finish. Potent and complex, but the excessive sweetness reduces the enjoyment and makes it more of a novelty.

(RBESG05, bottle) Head vanishes instantly, leaving a hazy dark red-brown body.  Aroma is very sweet, molasses, caramel, some toffee.  Taste is very sweet, molasses, caramel, cherry, light chocolate.  Full sticky body.  Decent, but only in small portions -- too big for a doppel.

Bottle. RBESG -05. 
Dark brown. Figs and dried fruits nose. Oxidized? Soy sauce mouthfeel. Very malty. Fiery. Sticky but not overly.
Bottle, RBESG 2005, Grand Tasting. Very dark reddish brown colour, no head. Strong malty sweet aroma with caramel. VERY sweet wort, molasses and caramel flavour. Sticky. Too sweet for me.

(Bottle 100 cl) Dark brown with a warm, orange glow, very small head. Sweetish scent of dates and overripe plums. And you find the exact same impressions in the flavours. Fruity all the way through - like sweet, tasty desert wine. Josh is right, this is a malt lovers paradise. Extremely delicate. 120805

Mahogany colour, almost no head. Aroma from soysauce, vinegar and roasted malts. Flavour is pretty much the same, but with some sweet dark fruits finish. Full bodied. Somewhat sticky mouthfeel in finish.

(On bottle at RBESG 2005)Thanx to The Sk8terboy fo bringing, have been craving it for a long time. dark caramelcolour, no head.Fantastic aroma; a blend of smoked herring, dark sugar and alkohol. SOOO smoothit had to try it a few time to really get the difference of aroma and mouthfeel. The alcohol tears nicely on the tounge. very cloying finish that not even the 10,5% can handle.

Bottled at RBESG 2005.
Rating #1000.
Brown coloured with a small fast disappearing beige head.
Sweet malty aroma with notes of caramel.
Nice sweet flavour with lots of caramel, dried fruits and notes of liquorice.
Well hidden alcohol.
Bottle RBESG. Could pass for cough-syrup. Malty, herby, deep black color. No real carbonation. Some fruit in the palate. Alc. is very well hidden.

Bottled @RBESG05
Dark nut brown with shades of cherry red, no head. Aroma of burnt sugar. Sweet, toffeeish flavor. Some pure sugar and some burnt sugar. Burning alcohol in the finish.

Stylish 100 cl bottle w/ resealable cap. Served in Carlsberg Semper Ardens Christmas Ale goblet. Slightly hazy reddish brown. Moderate, tan head that all but disappears. The aroma is sweet and fruity (pineapple), heavily malty. The flavor is hugely, sweetly malty w/ tons of fruit. Some pepper-notes, too. Moderately alcoholic. Thick, thick, syrupy mouthfeel. Surprisingly drinkable. Thanks for the trade, René!

Dark brown colour with a small fine light brown head.  Roasted malty nose, some caramel sweetness and hints of fruit. Flavor is malty with licorice, vanilla, spices and the list goes on. Palate is very thick and syrup like. Many thanx to Rene (sk8viking) for this fantastic beer.

Pours dark brown with a fine though disappearing tan head. Rather mild but fresh aroma of fruit and malt with notes of berries and pineapple. Very sweet flavor. Lots of malt with roasted tones and some sour fruit. Notes of caramel and spices. Extremely thick mouthful and a very special beer.

Thanks a lot Ask (ToolHead) for bringing this for tasting to my shop!!

Bottled: Red brown coloured. Dosnt have much head. Medicin, spice  and some fruitsweetness in the aroma. Flavour of liqourice, spices and sweetness. Is fullbodied and has a nice alcoholbite. Ends on a sweet note, with some alcoholwarmth. Nice one. Thanks sk8viking for this.

Very sweet nose, nice fruityness, some pineapple. Very dark brown body with a small tan head, this beer seems rather thick. Good sweetness in the flavor, actually its like caramel and sugar, good alcohol bite and very sticky. Good one.

A deep red  beer with a small orange head. The aroma is extremely sweet with notes of caramel and alcohol. The flavor is like thick sugar water with notes of alcohol and caramel. Nice one. Thanks to sk8vikings wife for bringing this gem to Denmark.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2005 Bottle Thanks to my Wife. Dark Red-brown color and small head. Sweet fruity caramel aroma and heavy sweet caramel fruity light alcoholic taste. Full body and a sweet sweet light alcoholic finish.

Dark reddish brown coloured. It leaves legs on the side of the glass! Loads of dark fruits and caramel in the aroma. Raisins, caramel, coffee and liquorice notes in the flavour. Notes of the coffe liquor produced by Achouffe. Very thick and sirupy mouthfeel. Thanks a lot to the wife of Rene (sk8viking) for bringing a bottle of this to Denmark.

How often I have been to Vetters as my friend worked there. Thanks Martina for visiting us and bringing back the memories with these huge gigantic bottles! Coffee and chocolate nose with hints of raisons and plums.  Opaque color with hints of red. Tastes like sugar syrup, with raisons, chocolate. Syrupy with a woody finish. Flat carbonation what could come through the transport. Nice and as daboskabouter says - a dessert!

Dark brown appearance.  Thick, syruppy.  Oats are dominant in the nose.  Chocolate, vanilla and brown sugar also evident.  Thick, very sweet fudgey body, brown sugar, rounded off by a light hop bitterness.  Certainly a unique drinking experience, great dessert beer, but I dont really like dessert.  A different tasting experience

Dark brown; no head; heavy nose - molasses, good tamari soy sauce; slightly salty; sweet, oily body; touch of marzipan, soy, demerara, hint of mandarin orange (again with the Japanese theme).  Sweet and thick without being cloying or syrupy.  A good meal.
deep ruby red  colour.  rye bread aroma.  nicely complex notes of vanilla, toffee, brown sugar and butter.  rye bread with butter finish.  very different, in a good way.
Vinous nose, dark ruby, almost no head. Port like flavour, treacle and a fruit aftertaste. Sweet and kind, a sponge toffeeness to this one.
This is beer juice!? IN konzentrate JA, JA. No head, almost black in color. Thick and syrupy. Caramel aroma, buttery, milky, chocolaty.  Huh, so BIG, mega sweet. Where is the water?

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2005 Man, never had a beer like this one.  Its like drinking a barley liquor.  Thick as syrup and very sweet.  I dont think I could drink more that two.  It was a great experience, Thanks JPKnight for this one.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2004 Vetters 33 is a beer quite different than any I am used to in my world, but I stumbled upon it while visiting my roommate in Heidelberg, Germany.  Just as Pivo said, it has a strong, malty nose and appears to be thick and syrupy.  The flavor is much sweeter than what I am used to in a beer, but its very digestable - I like Oakes asian reference...

Well, with 33 Plato this is bound to be rich and malty, with a
 high alcohol component. Even the nose brings a certain alcohol 
aroma mixed with a stong malt scent. Syrupy. Prune-like or brandy-like with a very long taste profile. This beer just keeps giving and packs a whallup. 
The brewpub is located in the old town of Heidelberg and offers
German pub grub. If you are there with a party, try the large pan
of sausage and potates for 4 people.
